physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It features a large bouquet of flowers on the right, against a brown background and decorated with a variety of little animals such as birds, foshes, and sea creatures. The panel is outlined with a border of various flower blooms. The main body of the kain panjang is also decorated with various flower blooms, set against a green background. There is a signature on the bottom-right of the batik kain panjang.
sgcool_label_text: The buketan motif or a large bouquet of flowers is depicted on the brown kepala or broad vertical panel of the batik.  It is decorated with vignettes of amusing animals such as a standing elephant and a hare staring at plants.  On the badan or main design field, a variety of floral blooms embellish the green background.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Jane Hendro Pekalongan ‘67”.
